posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6500480
depends if you are practicing right or just mindlessly get it done mentality etc. if you dont actively do anythign to improve and just repeat osme exercise you arent really sure why you are doing, you obviously wont improve even after hundreds of hours. if you slow down and analyze your practice exercises and actively look for mistakes and correct them, then you should improve.

for example, if you are doing ellipses or line weight or feathering/crosshatching and just scribble lines, thats not accomplishing anything. you are finishing the exercise, but its the same mistakes as the day before. you just wasted 15 minutes doing it or whatever.

when im in portrait mode, i'll do loomis heads from free references and full construction, etc. takes about half hour to do a head or two, depending on angle/difficulty/if i render it at all. the point is i am focusing on measurements, anatomy and actively measuring and trying to improve my portraits and construction. i'm not just filling a page with doodle heads and calling it practice. sometimes ill do the literal loomis plates.

practice makes perfect, but practicing wrong will always be wrong.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6500540
I am doing the best to improve as quickly as I can regarding what I want to get competent at (general character design, lineart, detailing, dynamic poses, explicit coom, hands, foreshortening, faces and expressions, and related while also ignoring stuff like rendering, environments, mecha, etc. for now just to get good faster at character art), so internalizing and practicing often core techniques and methods is a must for consistent and increasing quality in what I produce. So you can't say I am someone who just draws a full page of mindless Loomis heads and call it a day since my focus is clear from the start, tho I might need to produce more finished pieces and learn how to doodle just for fun in general as well.

>>6502758
You don’t need to master anatomy or any other skill to do well in it. Stylizing is far more important for success. It needs to look good for people to want to spend money on it. Think about finishing some of your sketches. It’s more important to be able to create a finished, colored piece that can stand on its own. Clients don’t want sketches or perfect anatomy, they want pretty pictures. Just have solid fundies and start stylizing. Don’t get stuck striving for mastery, it’s a beg-trap.

The based artists will be the ones who have nothing to do with AI and, frankly, even high-end digital painting software, which is going to be more and more integrated with AI.
Picrel is from a MAD Magazine film parody. The illustration was drawn in pencil and inked with a dip pen. The central figure is a caricature of Burt Reynolds. On the far left, in glasses, is a caricature of Gloria Steinem, a prominent feminist activist. She wasn't in the film being parodied, but the artist, Mort Drucker, included her as a gag, as she would obviously disapprove of the women swooning over then-sex symbol Reynolds. That's human art. You are all fucking stupid if you think there aren't going to be laws put on this shit. Artists not only hate it, but AI was made with art used nonconsensually. Then, once it became apparent it was not only a fad but a potential danger to society, legal restrictions were put in place. The only way to 100% safely make an anime based on AI is to have it made in house, with art that you have the rights to. It's funny to think that Western art - primarily Disney's Snow White - inspired Ultraboy, who then inspired the proto anime art style of the seventies, which was deconstructed by the rough and tumble style eighties anime is known for, which continued down the pipeline of cleaning up and refining until it became what we know today.

In a manner of speaking, Pregolden-age Western art created twenty first century Western art, in the most roundabout way possible.

Lacks line confidence. You have generally got things going in the right direction but you need to not make composite ("hairy") lines.
>>6489478
>>6489618
For coloring, you need to learn your tools a bit better. That as a completed image should only take you 3-4 hours of work at the absolute most. Things like using masks, auto-color tools, how to paint bucket effectively, and so on immensely helps with that kind of cel shading you're doing.
Try disabling Ctrl+Z for a month.


Basically your problem is that you are taking too long to complete each stage of a drawing. Accept your imperfections with the knowledge that producing art faster makes you better.
Making 5, increasingly-detailed sketches overlaid on top of each other using confident strokes takes less time than the 2-3 you did there using unconfident strokes.

Additionally your commission sheet needs to have its basics easily grasped from a twitter/deviantart/etc thumbnail. Offered levels of polish and prices primarily. Never use "percentages" to change pricing, and discounts look better than additional fees.

No, talent and intelligence are not synonymous. High IQ can certainly aid in the acquisition and mastery of certain skills, but there are many factors that contribute to success in the arts, including creativity, motivation, hard work, experience, and education. Success in the arts cannot be reduced solely to one's IQ. While IQ may be a predictor of certain types of intelligence, it does not encompass the full range of skills, abilities, and traits that are required for success in the arts. Sargent's fluency in multiple languages and his education in various subjects helped him to become well-rounded and knowledgeable, but it was his exceptional talent, hard work, and determination that ultimately led to his success as a portraitist.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6497806
I recommend grouping values to make things less muddy. It could help to start with bigger shapes and two values first (your main light and shadow) then go into the smaller details and more nuanced values later. Another way to clean it up would be paying more attention to your edge control. To me it seems as if you went first with a small brush, which would explain the white spaces, but you don't seem to have a clear image of what the final product would look like.

I agree with the guy that a two stone study would be good but I don't know if I would agree with treating your current progress as an underpainting because the layers look very rough and thick to me the more you add the more uneven it will become. This was my mistake with my first oil painting 4 years ago. Instead of knowing how to take away from the paint and be decisive with my actions, I kept adding more over my mistakes up only to end up with my layers, texture, surface, and brushstrokes all fucked up so I had to use my thinner to wipe layers of wasted paint and repaint over after destroying all the preexisting paint. Thinking you can just correct your mistakes by painting over like with digital is a common mistake for people painting for the first time.

I also don't know if I would agree with the comment on warm tones, because temperature is more advanced than values. If you don't know your light and shadows adding more varied temperature will most likely make things even more confusing (mistake I do a lot the time). I recommend a zorn palette for temperature work, but I myself am terrible at temperature so I really can't give any advice beyond the basics and beginner stuff.

That’s not my drawing of Dem. I was just showing you what I meant by form. Notice how her face is depicted as a 3 dimensional shape. This is what your piece lacks.
Mimicking Alan’s style is actually really easy. If you want to get good at that you should collect shots from the show. Or use his artwork as a reference sheet. If yours looks off trace the reference to get proportions of the face then attempt to redraw it without tracing.
But you should definitely practice human anatomy by drawing poses from reference and studying the muscles.

Good work, altogether.

>>6499643
Use brushes made for ink and let the materials work for you. Krink makes something called like the K40 or something which has an unusual applicator included with the ink. I recommend you play with some really high quality alcohol based inks and you’ll see what I mean about letting the medium work for you. Pens are honestly lame if you want to make loose artsy shit or anything that isn’t academically western. You can try water/charcoal base inks but I don’t have any experience with them but their properties are different than alcohol or xylene base inks.

posts.com:
>>6490726
>What did you use to learn colouring in black and white?


I grow up with traditional medium before switching to digital. The skills transfer nicely when you do shading on digital.
I also spent lot of time studying digital colouring/painting. From greyscale to color. That definitely help me a lot when it comes to determining value in drawing, though it's far from perfect.
Studying comic, traditional artists, or even black and white artwork is also a great way to learn.

>>6490823
>I'm curious what your routine for getting to this point was.
I'm the sort of guy that only draw when I find something interesting.
For routine, I keep in mind the mistake I made on previous work and try not to do it on my next work. The gap between finding new inspiration to draw my next work is the time I spend learning and practicing to fixed my mistakes.
I'm blessed enough with a good career so art is just a hobby for me to wind down. There's no use stressing about it, in my case.

>>6495210
>Got any inking/line art tips or tutorials?
I notice beginner tend to zoom too close on their canvas which result in shaking, uneven thickness in lineart. It's okay for detail, but for general shape of the drawing it's not a good practice. Try getting used to drawing without zooming too much.
Also practice on line confidence. Try not too rely too much on Ctrl+Z if you can! Sometimes erasing is better.
If you don't have any mood for drawing, watching speedpaint can sometimes inspire you to draw.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
AI art's real cool ability would be to streamline animation processes.

Imagine instead of drawing 2400 pictures, you just did spot work on same pictures, and every time you did the work got more to what you would draw. Like you just put in character sheets, (mapped to every angle, like the 3d presentation of 2d art) built standard packs to understand drawn rules about hair or accessories to a basic extent, and over time with improvement it figured out what you wanted. All that time spent on inbetweens spent on just making the finished product.

That sounds cool, that sounds like a benefit to animation. Programs that can help to speed up the craft, leave people more time to make more material, that's the net benefit. It'd be like getting mad we don't use printing presses with specific blocks anymore for printing that you have to take out by hand and swap and shit, typing a prompt into a computer is still an action of an individual, it's still the performance of crafting, it's still art you made with your actions.

posts.com:
I had a nightmare yesternight.
I was back in school, and there was some kind of project, where everyone had to make a piece of creative work, which would then be shown to the whole class.
I wanted to make a drawing, so that was what I set out to do. I worked hard on it. Poured my soul into it. It was perfect. I loved it.
So it came time to display my works. It was shown through a projector, and everyone saw it.
The class erupted in laughter. Vile, wicked laughter. They made fun of me and my works. Not just the poor technical skill, but also the subject which I chose. It was terrible. I sunk deeper into my seat, hoping to stay unnoticed by the others, who were laughing. The unbearable feeling of shame in that moment.
After that whole ordeal was over, anyone who would cross my path would laugh at me, and make a mean comment about the work I created.
The worst of the vile laughter and commentary came from a group of girls, one of whom was my crush. That was terrible. I couldn't conceive how this happened.
The comments were all so personal, too. I won't say here what they said, but it really did hurt me.
I remember some cheeky fucker said "I know how he did it", and went to the whiteboard and drew my work using my construction method, but made a really shitty version of it, which prompted even more laughter from the audience.
I remember mutilating one of them, tearing his limbs off, burning the skin off his face, but he just refused to die. No, the whole time he was taunting me! Taunting me and my character, even as I was hurting him and mutilating him.
I know it's just a bad dream, but that really took a hit to my morale.
I'm tired.

posts.com: I mostly draw digital, but the one time I did a large scale illustration with pastels, it was really freeing. Shit just looked how I wanted it without having to tinker with settings or having to find just the eight brush. Adding values with pencils is also a lot more intuitive than doing the same digitally. Don't get me wrong, a lot of digital art tools can be a huge help over traditional (namely the ability to correct at any time), but a lot of traditional tools are simply more intuitive than trying to mimic them digitally.

>>6492190
bring a sketchbook with you wherever you can and try to find little pockets of time to draw in it.

accept that you will never think that you are "good enough" and try to find fun in the process itself and in making improvements.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
"just draw" is great advice to learn, but if you are practicing and want to make finished pieces, then you can't "just draw". You have to think and decide good things to draw. You can't just draw anything like some redditors here try to say. Drawing random incomprehensible shapes is a waste of your time if you're trying to make something good.

Make a schedule for yourself and turn off all distracts, then when time's up you can put the pencil down and stop worrying. If you end up drawing nothing during that time, then try to come up with a lesson plan or a goal for next time. But that time should be reserved for you sitting in front of the paper to make you used to it.

>>6494108
Go for it man. I've studied with people who became successful artists starting at the age of 40 or 50, all the cynicism here is a meme. The field is hard but if you work at it and really think about the work you're doing and who it's for you can definitely find a niche.

The best advice I can give you is to try and find classes or studios by you. Just walk-ins for figure drawing, not an art school or anything like that. Self study can definitely work for some people but you'll always improve more efficiently if you're with a community and have people giving you live advice. Watching How to Draw streams and pirating art books is the fastest way to stagnate if you don't know exactly what you're doing.

Oh, i just paint where i sleep, and then I open the windows to ventilate the room, and put the painting on the balcony to dry.
All my creative belongings can be placed on the table, and I put the canvases on a small tabletop easel. Before that, I cover the table with newspapers so as not to stain it. So there are options, bro, if you really want to paint with oils! A separate room is not necessary.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6500710
Compositional armature is the way visual elements are organized to create balance, stability, and harmony in the image, and to guide the viewer's attention. It serves as a framework for the image and is made using techniques like the rule of thirds, diagonal lines, symmetry, and balance. A strong compositional armature makes the image more visually appealing and helps communicate the intended message effectively.

>>6488300
This answer applies to any artist that's teaching something: Is their teaching method clicking with you and getting you excited to draw and learn? If so, then go for it.

Life is too short to worry about whether you're learning "the right thing" or not. If the artist has a style and approach that's appealing to you and you want similar end results then great! Not many artists share their process so candidly, and if there's tons of resources and they teach in a way that clicks with you then don't take those for granted and just start drawing. If you change your mind and want to switch tracks then you'll still have learned something anyway.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
go to lifedrawing classes with skeletal and muscular diagrams to your side, learn to be expressive first in short amount of time, do quick studies, 30's one min then five and so on. begin with bones try to draw a skeleton from memory, then do the same with muscles, and finaly you can move on to cloth studies, but that will be last. Learn to identify bone landmarks.
Last minor tip, do it on a big canvas, a big sized newsprint paper and some chalk (personally I prefer conte crayons) and draw from your shoulder not your wrist.

>>6500181
step 3 and 2 are best done in tandem with each other, gesture works well as a warmup,

>>6500211
bargue plates, the most valuable thing you can learn in proportion, proportion is what nearly EVERY drawing fucks up completely, perspective may be fucked, but when people cant draw something in perspective they avoid doing so, but proportion is fundamentally the most important concept you need to do, I mean, when you draw a stick figure, you have a head, then the proportion from the head to the waste where the legs start, then with how long you make the arms, you can, within 10 seconds, analyze the pose you want to draw and see if its fundamentally fucked up or not, but if you suck at proportion, you may find out hour 2 that the arm is about 1 foot longer than it should be, the hand is half the size it should be, and what the fuck is going on with that leg.

bargue plates, has fantastic reference material in the book, which is online for free, doing that along with drawing from life, just shit on your desk, shit in your house, whatever, will also instill some level of perspective.

from here, learn how to place basic 3d objects in space from scratch, this is just perspective and an application of proportion.

and from here, I would probably look into watts "Bridgman’s Anatomy with Erik Gist" or youtubes deciphering bridgeman,

this should be able to take you to where you want to get to.

remember, proportion > perspective > anatomy/construction in that order.

along the way you will also learn value just by application of what you are doing,

>>6496152
Here are some steps to help you learn color theory and apply it to your art:

1. Study the basics of color theory: Start by learning about the color wheel, color harmonies, and the properties of colors, such as hue, saturation, and brightness.

2. Experiment with colors: Use a color wheel and different media to experiment with color combinations and see how colors interact with each other.

2. Practice color mixing: Try mixing colors to create new shades and tints, and learn how to create different color schemes, such as complementary, monochromatic, and analogous.

3. Observe color in real life: Study the colors in nature, architecture, and everyday objects to gain a better understanding of how colors work together in the real world.

4. Use references: Study the work of artists you admire and see how they use color in their art. This can help you understand how to create moods, evoke emotions, and create depth in your own artwork.

5. Apply what you’ve learned: Start incorporating color theory into your artwork by planning color schemes, experimenting with different color combinations, and making color a conscious part of your creative process.

6. Keep practicing: The more you practice, the better you will become at using color in your art. Don’t be afraid to make mistakes, as this is a natural part of the learning process.

I'd suggest more decisive lines, try to visualize what you want to put down before you do. >>6458574
I was toying around with threads and I got it to look decent, though the perspective is off.
As for the texture, I made Triangle pattern and used the bend tool or w/e in Kirta since I was trying to see how it would look, trying to go for that camo netting pattern thats pretty hard to draw, In the end it was just a test, since I was learning about using textures and what not.
The hard part about the treads is that it it looks off if the perspective is off. It took me a bit to figure out how shade these and show that they are treads on the track, but you need a good underline or if not, dont strictly follow the underline if you know the perspective is off. I could fix it but I moved on for this until I get some coloring practice in.

posts.com:
the problem with talent is that it’s too reductive. It assumes there 1 magical trait out there that makes you good at art when in reality there’s dozens of interconnected ones. And if you lack in one area you very likely make up in another one.

Someone with a strong sense of color has artistic talent, someone with amazing visual memory has talent, someone with great spacial intelligence has talent, someone who’s just incredible creative has talent, etc…
And while some people have more of these than others, few people have literally none of them.

Sure some people will be talented in areas you aren’t but they will also still stumble in other areas. And blaming talent for them being all around better than you is just cope. Someone with great color sense might always be better than you at painting but it’s not because of that that you’re still drawing floating anime girls on white backgrounds and you refuse to draw more time consuming intricate drawings with lots of interesting interconnecting pieces.

>>6498170
It’s a misconception that drawing cartoons is easy mode just because it’s not as complex as realism. It took me years of filling sketchbooks with form studies and drawing cartoon characters using construction methods via picrel to finally become proficient at it. I spent my 20s doing this just to get good at drawing cartoons. Finally toward my latter 20s, I was able to draw stylized cartoons that looked good and not like wonky permabeg studies with terrible line control and flawed understanding of volumes.

There are still fundamentals that need to be learned, instilled and fully integrated. This takes years. It’s not a simple matter of “cartoons are simple so that means they’re easy”. Permabegs have no concept of volume or line control, which are essential precursors to drawing ANYTHING pleasant.

>>6493174
The statement that "pornography is the highest form of pure visual art" is incorrect and oversimplifies the role and purpose of art. Art is a form of human expression that has the power to evoke a wide range of emotions, spark creativity, and provide insight into the human experience.

Art also has the ability to uplift, inspire, and foster empathy. Through art, we can explore the beauty of life, the complexities of the human condition, and the majesty of the natural world. Art has the power to bring people together and create a sense of shared experience and understanding.

In contrast, pornography is often created for the sole purpose of sexual gratification and is focused on objectifying and exploiting people. It can damage the soul and harm society by promoting unhealthy attitudes and behaviors towards sex and relationships.

Art has the power to do so much more than just evoke a single emotion, it has the ability to challenge, educate, and transform the world. Therefore, to say that pornography is the highest form of pure visual art is a narrow and misguided perspective that fails to fully appreciate the depth and breadth of what art can accomplish.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6495945
Monsters in Silent Hill are actually real anon. They're given shape by the town's supernatural forces. There's actually a lot of realistic design principles in how Masahiro Ito designs his monsters and he emphasizes the weight of their appendages and proportions through their posture and animation.
>in this interview, concept artist for the evil within 2, ikumi nakamura says something similar as to why she dislikes the concept of the keeper in the first game
You do realize that Ikumi was the primary concept artist of the first Evil Within right? Funny you'd bring up The Keeper, since it's basically a conceptual ripoff of Pyramid Head while lacking any weight or finesse in his animations. Evil Within gets away with this because the monsters are literally conjured from a mindscape but the same can't be said for a lot of Ito's work on Silent Hill. Even Ikumi's monsters in Evil Within lack that sense of weight and realism to their movements by comparison.

Saying whether or not a monster is real =/= design philosophy. The former is story/conceptual intent while the latter is dictated by actual aesthetic principles and artistic execution. One can inform the other but they're not mutually exclusive.

>>6496120
That was my first impression. Where Birkin's design and heft and weight, this feels too float-y and almost superhero-like.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6495884 does a pretty good job at making things much more cohesive. I'd like to add to it by suggesting you push the contrast into forming a sequence where most of the body is lean and relatively normal, then much more musclebound, and finally just outright swollen. I would also recommend looking into actual diseases (if you can stomach that sort of thing) for much more grounded design elements. Things like skin abnormalities, parasites, teratomas, etc. (lore or theming could decide some of what you want to lean on) could give you much more convincing elements to work with.

I played around with the idea a bit in picrel. If I were to go at it again I'd probably push the scale difference much further.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6488939
This. You can't compare panels from a serialized comic book to one-off illustrations that 90% of every piece of art you have seen are. Not only is there a difference between the time limits each type of art are given to be completed, but there is a measured time limit that a person will on average look at of each.

Each panel of a comic is seen for at most a few seconds by a reader, just enough to read any text and understand what is happening in the image, then on to the next. It's absolutely NOT worth spending hours constructing and rendering every fucking panel and page. Despite that, Miura obviously spent more and more time doing exactly that, which contributed to his declining health and irritating his readers with delays.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I read a lot of comics not just manga, mostly Franco-Belgian BDs for the last few years but Berserk is one of the best I've read in terms of storytelling. Not the story or the writing itself, which is more subjective but there's nothing quite as fluid as Berserk in terms of action and panel flow. You're hooked in the first couple of pages and always waiting for those special cinematic moments that only Miura could pull off. This ability has been lost now with the assistants and his good friend Mori, who is also a talented mangaka. He has interesting stuff but it's different so it cannot be replicated, or even, continued.

There are many other great authors but few have this skill and the compelling story and characters. I'm not talking about art. If you go to any European comic store you understand that they have superior artistic standards but well, the stories are more like movies and don't produce the same effect manga does.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6489036
Vagabond is actually average at best. Good art but it's too clinical, too perfect for my taste. And the storytelling is terrible, it goes nowhere and there's no excitement whatsoever for any fights. No substance.

You can compare it to Vinland Saga, both detailed art but clearly too prepared, not fluid enough but at least VS has interesting characters.

Nothing wrong with clean artstyle btw, but the lines must have some sensuality in the curves, some courage. Masters of ligne claire had perfectly accurate line work but they expressed everything with the bare minimum of a single line and contained form.

To a similar extent you have Monkey Punch, who I consider to be one of the best mangakas of all time, a true Master of the line. To a whole different level compared to stuff like Vagabond, but I understand the more rigid and clean style can be more appealing at first, but the taste gets refined with age.

>>6490586
Thanks
He had ESP as a child, but lost it during some MK-Ultra-like experiments. They didn't seem particularly traumatic at the time, but he has lost his ESP since and feels that emptiness or gap ever since it was taken away from him.

He's very withdrawn and spends most of his time reading books, seeking forbidden knowledge on the dark web (I know it's a meme, but it's in more of a cyberpunk setting), doing parkour, and observing people from hiding spots. Hiding and parkour are about the only things he's good at, but is reasonably tech-savvy.

He's also not amazing in a fight, but his strength lies in setting up traps and stealthy takedowns. His weapon is a pair of brass knuckles if he does need to fight.

He basically just wants answers as to what the nature of his powers were when he was a kid, why they were taken, what impact it has on the country, etc. and infiltrates CIA facilities for this knowledge (and maybe some cool gear). The further he digs, the more dangerous it becomes. But what does he have to lose?

>>6396806
Soft shading/lighting with fewer steps. Gotta tweak the airbrush settings because default airbrush settings are often bad. If you use CSP, consider getting the “airy airbrush” tool. You can get similar results blocking in color on a higher layer then using a soft eraser, but a good airbrush will do that all on its own. Imo, it’s an essential tool for ani semi-realistic soft shading.

>>6498455
Like this. I used to have my pencil rest on my middle finger, but my thumb gets too sore from a tripod grip because I'm the type of person who will sit down and draw for hours on end without breaks. That's why now I usually use a very flexible grip so I can draw for an entire day straight without needing to take breaks. I realized that having my pencil on my ring finger gives me a wider reach and flexibility, I can make large sweeping motions so it's good for drafting and sketching while the tripod on the middle finger gives me more control and more precise detailing but it lacks reach and fluidity.

>>6498475
Nah, I switch between the two and I used to do the tripod grip as my main grip and my motor faculties are developed more than the average person. I still use that grip sometimes, especially when writing, but for long drawing sessions I don't. It's fine for 5 hours but any more than that I get carpal tunnel.

>>6496701
>>6496725
>The sketch became the lineart and stayed as one layer throughout
I see no wrong in this, exactly my work process.
I do have one question, are you, yourself unsatisfied with your own work flow and results, or do you want thing to look ''cleaner'' because only of outside opinions. Since there's nothing wrong for a piece to have strong or heavy lines. I do think your art has a lot of charm, I really like the bunny guys hair. Of course you can always improve thing like anatomy, gesture and so on. But if you want more cleaner/confident lines, I'd recommend practice line weight, avoid re-drawing lines atop on each other, just do one line at a time and connect them. If you are a /beg/inner or /int/ermediate in art, please use this thread to post pieces for critique or ask for advice.

RESIZE YOUR IMAGES TO ~1000 PIXELS wide using one of the following methods:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6497442
>my goals are to draw cute anime girls or whatever
>I can't even copy art right
if you're prioritizing copying, then you're on the right track already. doing fundamentals on the side is good, too (e.g. anatomy). the more fundamentals you know, the better you'll be able to learn from copying others. you can understand the their decision making process better, and their choices in abstraction.

if you're frustrated with your copying but can't say why, then you probably just need to work on developing a critical eye and bettering your accuracy (in addition to your mechanical skills if that's part of the problem). you have to get good at identifying what's wrong, and then fixing that. as long as it looks "wrong" to you, you can figure out why. think hard and compare carefully. be as specific as possible. be as specific as you know how to be. the self-improvement loop is:
>create art
>critique it (what's wrong with it, specifically?)
>use critique to identify specific weaknesses (e.g. "these hands look wrong")
>study and practice hard to patch these specific weaknesses you identified (e.g. draw 1000 hands from ref)
>repeat

you'll get better at critiquing yourself productively the better your fundamentals get, too. there are a lot of clever study techniques for improving in specific ways, but if you just do studies and never create art, you will get bored and burned out. likewise, if you just make shit and never critique and study, you will get frustrated with lack of progress. you have to join them together.

The general idea i have seen in stickies and other art places: observation, perspective, spatial awareness (rotate the cube, feel the form), any of the INT books from titans like loomis, vilpu, hamilpton and then master studies.
>>6496759
>no reason/attention
I wont deny the attention part. I am like all the other 99% art fags: the more fame the better! BUT you act like reading multiple beg books is waste of time or something. It isnt. It allowed me to comprehend why there are so many clashing advice regarding drawing. Its because there are roughly three distinct paths: gesture, observation and construction. All three ultimately leads to the same end result, but the way you get there is mad different. I wouldnt know this if i didnt do multiple beg books. They all teach the same but sometimes the diff between approaches and mindset is like day and night.

>free hand
>controlled hand
what does that mean?

understanding that you have a problem simplifying is helpful. if you feel overwhelmed by detail/complexity, try zooming out mentally and working from the biggest shapes you see to the smallest. if you get the largest proportions, angles and relationships right at the outset, you can work your way down into finer detail more confidently. reducing problems to smaller, solvable chunks is good advice for problem solving in general; but with drawing and painting, smaller, simpler problems usually mean bigger, more abstract shapes.

enveloping is a good way to do this, starting from the beginning. picrel is a crappy envelope I drew on your ref. I'm a retard but it helps me a lot. here are some videos I skimmed but they seem legit enough to get the idea across:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3OiYk58W--w
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gwevjSTz2yQ
